Dear Sheffield City Council,
The requester is making a meta request, the requestor is exercising their right of access to the recorded information you hold about the handling of the original request ICO REF:  IC-159669-K9T5. SCC REF: [NO REF PROVIDED] Title: Communication of records retention policy by Steve Eccleston.
On the 27th December 2020, I submitted a FOI request to the council, asking for details and records regarding how this policy of marking emails “not subject to FOI” was communicated to officers.
The council did not issue a response.
On the 12th of May 2022, the ICO issued a decision notice stating that the council must respond by 35 calendar days.
The council did not issue a response in the time specified in the decision notice.
The council in response to IC-159669-K9T5 stated: “But to the best of our knowledge, we hold no record “. This requestor is seeking to understand what searches for records were undertaken when responding to this request, and how the council requested recorded information from record custodians. In addition to, how the council handled this request.
Recorded information relevant to this request will include, but not be limited to: communication from the FOI team to the relevant parties who held requested information and records sought in IC-159669-K9T5. The responses in-turn received.   Any discussion how to respond to this request in-lieu of providing recorded information.
This is distinct from a request for internal review. As per the ICO guidance:
“You should not refuse to comply with a meta request because you have already carried out an internal review, or refuse to carry out an internal review because you have already complied with a meta request.
However, requesters may submit meta requests because they are dissatisfied with how you handled the original request.”
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear Marcus Combie,
Thank you for your request for information relating to correspondence
around the handling of FOI 2021-22-3027 relating to the use of "Not
subject to FOI" as an email header which we received on 01/07/2022.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
Please be aware that Sheffield City Council’s response to the global
COVID-19 pandemic has led to a reduction in resources across the Council,
meaning that we are currently dealing with a backlog of requests.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 29/07/2022, but we kindly ask for your patience
as we anticipate that there may be a delay in some cases. Please do not
hesitate to contact us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Mr Combie
Thank you for the meta request of 1 July 2022 regarding our handling of
your request FOI / 2020-21-3027, which was about the documentation of any
decision to use “Not Subject to FOI” on council emails. We apologise for
the delay in our response which was due on 29 July 2022. We have a
pandemic-induced backlog of requests, which has caused delays.
We are attaching the emails relating to this request and our response.
The redacted information on page 1 is out of scope.
We have removed personal information about more junior staff from email
headers and signatures. Section 40(2) exempts information in response to a
request if it is personal data belonging to an individual other than
yourself and it satisfies one of the conditions listed in the
legislation.(1) The condition contained in section 40(3A)(a) applies, that
disclosure would breach one of the data protection principles. The
principle is that, “Personal data shall be processed lawfully, fairly and
in a transparent manner...” (2) We do not consider that disclosing this
information to you, and consequently the public, is necessary or justified
in order to satisfy your information request and the requirements of the
FOIA. In the circumstances of this request there is no strong legitimate
interest that would override the prejudice to the rights and freedoms of
the data subject/s. We have therefore taken the decision that disclosing
this information to you would be unlawful.
(1) Amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 2000 contained in the
Data Protection Act 2018.
(2) GDPR EU2016, Article 5(1)(a).
There are two statements on page 8 we have redacted under section
36(2)(b)(i) because they contain opinions by a council officer about the
handling of your request, the disclosure of which would be likely to,
inhibit the free and frank provision of advice.
The opinions were supplied under the assumption that they would not be
released to the world at large. Initial views and formulations are
tendered as part of a process of internal scrutiny and validation before
being finally provided the requester. They are not necessarily accurate
and may give a misleading impression of the true situation.  The
disclosure of these opinions would be likely to have a direct impact, both
now and in the future, on an officer’s ability to debate these issues in a
free and frank manner and the process by which this discussion takes
place.
The public interest in the disclosure of the information is the principle
of the accountability and transparency of public authorities and their
decision-making processes. It would allow individuals to further
understand and participate in the issues debated.
The public interest in the maintenance of the exemption is the provision
of a safe space that allows officers to contribute to discussions without
concern about what may or may not be disclosed publicly. Without this,
participants may be reluctant to offer free and frank advice or share
concerns.
On balance, we do not consider it in the public interest to disclose this
information because of the ‘chilling effect’, which is that disclosure of
discussions would inhibit free and frank discussions in the future, and
that the loss of frankness and candour would damage the quality of advice
and deliberation and lead to poorer decision-making.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
Email: [3][Sheffield City Council request email]
